comments.body:
you are mutating the input argument, which IIUC is a ``DataFrame(index=columns)``; why don't you just create it in this function and return it?

This is a very hard to follow api the way you are doing it.

sorry for late reply @jreback 

yeah, agree, this doesn't look optimal, and input is indeed `DataFrame(index=columns)`, the reason not to create it in this function is `DataFrame` is defined in `frame.py`, if we want to use it, then need to import from `frame.py`, and this function is also gonna be used in `frame.py`, which will result in the conflict imports.

Any suggestions on how to work around it?
i remove the input arugment of `reordered_result` and return a dictionary in this method, and form into Dataframe in `frame.py` instead, is it a bit clearer?

comments.body:
Hi, @WillAyd @jreback 

I think this part has brought in quite conversations for a while, and i looked back at it again and feel there is still something could improve, so i re-designed the implementation a bit, and added quite detailed comment to explain.

The issue of `result` is, after the `self._aggregate` and `mangle_lamdbas`, if result is a `DataFrame`, the index of results will be obtained from callable name (e.g. `sum` -> `'sum'`, or `np.max` -> `'amax'`), or kept as is for string case (e.g. `'sum'` -> `'sum'`), or a parsed lambda func (e.g. `lambda x: min(x)` -> `'<lambda>'`), and index will be sorted.

so, if the call to function is `df.agg(aa=(C2, sum), ab=(C1, max), ac=(C1, np.max), ad=(C2, lambda x: min(x)), ae=(C1, sum))`, the order of functions is `C1: [max, np.max, sum]` and `C2: [sum, lambda]`, but it will look like something below in `results`:
```
             C2   C1
<lambda>      1  NaN
amax        NaN  4.0
max         NaN  4.0
sum        18.0  6.0
```
So for C2, it now has `[lambda, sum]` in result, and C1 has `[amax, max, sum]`, you can see order has changed, previously i used `[::-1]` to reorder, but this has sceanrios which cannot solve. Therefore, I decide to find the func name in index, and its position, and do a reordering for `s`, which you see in `reorder_mask` clause. And afterwards, we still need to replace those names with the names users provided in the call, e.g. `aa, ab, ae` etc, and those are unchanged in the latest commit.

The reason to have the mask is, if the result is a DataFrame and there is only one column being used for aggregation, e.g. `df.agg(aa=(C1, sum), ab=(C1, mean))`, there will be no re-sort in index, and the order is the same as called in function.

I know this might bring in a lot of confusions, but i have tried many scenarios for corner cases, seems this solution works quite good, and overall this is to achieve 3 things: 
1. the index name of aggregated dataframe has the same order of appearance as in the call, 
2. the column names of aggregated dataframes has the same order of appearance of column names as in the call, 
3. the aggregated result mapping is correct. 

Many thanks for your precious time reviewing this PR and would love to hear your feedbacks! thanks in advance! @WillAyd @jreback
emm, i _think_ CI failure is irrelevant
